commentBody: Haven’t finished the puzzle, and probably won’t for a while, but wanted to register kudos for any puzzle that includes GRACE HOPPER

Tough Friday. 20 minutes. Really struggling in the SE. Had a bit of Natick situation with DRE/DONA/SEATS/DIP, all of which made sense to me, the two Downs being valid answers and the two crosses being proper names that could have just as easily been the right ones. Had to play around with it a lot before I got DRU/TONI/SUITS/TIPS
I confidently filled in Ada Lovelace for 11 down.

ITOO liked this puzzle.  How could INOT. Nice symmetry for those two answers.  I thought I was in for a tough ride when a pass through the acrosses yielded very little.  Luckily, as often seems to be the case, the downs were friendlier.  I caused myself some flyspecking by inserting chili rather than CHILE, but caught that fairly quickly.
It was tougher than many past Fridays, but not impossible.  Made you think. I like that type of puzzle.
A tough workout, but totally fair.  This is how puzzles ought to be.

"That crossword lover doesn't have a phone?"
"Nah, he's off the grid."

("How puzzling...")
Felt extremely easy then almost hopeless then it was over. Surprisingly intense & demanding solve given that it didn't actually take that long
Amazing how all it takes is one or two breakthroughs for the pieces to fall in place after getting nothing on the first pass! I thought I’d be OFFTHEGRID on this one.
I thought the SW corner was going to end me, but I finally got it sorted out. Love an Agard puzzle!
Was 100% sure that 57A was CHICKENFAT.  My mouth started watering as I filled it in.  I think every letter was wrong.

I did not know Grace Hopper, and entered it as HOTPER, with TEAK as the cross, which I was sure of. So who on earth is this heroine EYKE then? Took me a minute to wise up. 
Nice puzzle, very chewy but quite digestible.

“Components of some make-overs”

I had   - - IRDOS.

Brain instantly shouts “WEIRDOS!”

Yes, I am one.
Was it a mistake that 5A appeared in today's puzzle instead of yesterday's?  Seems like it might have helped some folks who were less than thrilled.
Stuck forever with "PAWS"/"WONT YOU SEE", whereas I learned "Colleen" as Irish slang today. Fun and fast solve! I think I updated my PB.

Happy to see nothing falling OFF THE GRID tonight.

But, as always, when I try to solve a week-ender with the kids and the t.v. screaming in the same room as me, it seemed impenetrable. I thought for sure we had another beast on our hands (after my near 1.5 hour solve, yesterday.

Turned off the tube and got the kids in bed and knocked it out in 20 minutes. Phew!

Really, totally enjoyed this one the whole way!
Anyone else try Nora, from "A Doll's House," for 31D?  Sounded just like her.
I was awful today. I took a perfectly fun and interesting grid and couldn’t even beat my Sunday average with it. I’m going straight to bed.

That was a breeze.  Nice refreshing solve after yesterday.  Just over half my Friday average time compared to yesterday’s 20% over.

I thought red handed might refer to catching a fly ball without a glove.  I remember a red hand after I attempted it long ago…

In her column, Deb said "try to find some crosswordese". 
Well I guess TMI, BRIE, ERA and EVES  don't quite rise to the level of being croswordese, but they're pretty common in crosswords, and not so much IRL. (Maybe a case could be made that pluralized EVES only really live in crosswords)?

But still, a good challenging puzzle, with the proper names, Americanisms, and  initialisms solvable from the crosses. 

My only nit to pick is with "Red-handed". Seems more than a bit strained to me, and I never would've understood it without Deb's column.

TONI
INOT

Is kinda cool

Once again, listening to the Warriors game while I solved (The horror! The horror!) and wasn't paying attention to how things were oging with the puzzle until I finally bailed on the game and saw a lot of empty squares.  Autopilot hadn't worked as well as I thought it would and I had some work to do. 

OFF THE GRID sank Ada Lovelace and I had to do a look-up for GRACE.  And who know about CHILE and Antarctica?  Everyone but me? 

A Friday of a puzzle, and just right to prepare for a possible crusher of a Saturday.  Thank you, Willa Angel and Erik, I feel better already.
I wanted 55A to be Queer Pride but Superboy’s gf wasn’t having it.
Good stuff. Fresh and fun.
I liked everything about this puzzle, the constructors, their cluing, the fill, and even Deb's column. Did I get it all? No of course not. But that didn't stop me from enjoying it. Thanks guys!
Ken and Spade two days in a row ?

I can appreciate this was a good, properly hard Friday puzzle. For me, however, it was impossibly difficult.

With great effort I did the top 60% myself, despite unknowns such as I TOO, LUIS, and GRACE HOPPER. FLY BALL I only got when I was missing F and B. Why does one catch it Red-handed, exactly, and what is it anyway? The column has told me by now - it was the sort of clue I will never be able to get as a Polish person.

BRIE as clued confused me for a long time, too. I know BRIE the cheese, obviously, but I've never eaten it or even seen it on a cracker. Is topping crackers with BRIE popular in the US?

The bottom section defeated me. I've never heard PASTA WATER called "liquid gold". HAW flakes were alien to me. I have no idea who Superboy and his crush LANA are. ADA is just one of those American abbreviations I can never remember - there are just so many of them! I'm familiar with many Hills, but not DRU. ONE AND DONE I came up with only with many crosses, and it's not a phrase I *know*. 

I didn't understand why READY OR NOT was clued with "Seeking comment?" Ok, I checked the column. Yeah, nah, that was not gettable for somebody who has never played hide and seek with Americans.

With word checks I filled the grid but... No blue star. Review did not help. PAwS/wONT looked good... I only got that with a check of the whole puzzle 😢

So yeah, a good puzzle, but one of those unsolvable for me, a Polish guy with idiosyncratic interests - unsolvable without aid, anyway.

"OFFTHEGRID?"

Thursday's HORDE was a CRIMEDRAMA!

Why the OCCULT PHASE from this USERBASE
When a letter, like a FLYBALL left its usual space? 
Then TOUTS took to SPADE and lifted mean SOD
What DRU their ire?
It was a TMI fire.

DONTYOUSEE?
Variety is the FREETRADE of puzzleLAND.

ITOO, wish more solvers would
try constructors who could
DARE to CRAM and SLIDE words! 
Take your SHIP past the TIP and solve that iceberg!

Be the TASTER of quirky CAKE.
Be the RAJA of your solving mistakes!
HAVEAHEART and prePEAR
CANISMAJOR  (and autocheck) will HOIST you there - 

Forget the win,
The PLAYMONEY that got you in.
Be the TASTER of all crossword BAIT
OUST the FRAIL and TEENY hate.

Imagine how BITTERSWEET your published grid appears when CHILE solvers cuss your derrière. 

Glad Dan's not ONEANDDONE. 
READYORNOT, I hope HES just begun.
He SLEW it for me -
Butt of course, there's always one!

SUITS me!

Today's fine construction by Willa Angel Chen Miller and Erik Agard was also verily appreciated. No fleas on those two!
This was hard to crack open at first, and I had to look up a few things, but once things got going there was no stopping me. A very satisfying solve.

The only liquid gold I have ever heard of was breast milk. It fit, but I read the clue a second time when the crosses didn’t work and then saw cooking byproduct?! 🤣 🤣 Okay, time to put the thinking cap back on. I’ve been laughing at myself for the last thirty minutes for that epically wrong answer. PASTA WATER makes so much more sense 🤦🏼‍♀️ Beautifully constructed puzzle. Thank you for starting off my weekend with a laugh at my own expense!!
I definitely don't cook enough, it seems! I was thinking bone broth or ghee for liquid gold. Should I be doing more than straining the pasta water out...? Much to consider!
A 30-minute Friday breath of fresh air after yesterday's downer.  Thank you, crossword gods.

Grace Hopper was the first to identify an actual bug interfering with the operation of a computer. She found it in a Mark II computer in 1947. Being the excellent Naval officer she was, she inserted in actual insect (a moth) into her log. We have had computer and program bugs ever since. 

I would not have learned this if I had not done today's crossword puzzle!

I’d be interested to find out what instruments are made of pear wood. 
I’ve seen guitars and other stringed instruments with spruce, rosewood, mahogany, koa, sapele, ash, maple, and ebony.

Assuming that Superboy was something to do with Superman, I first had Lois for LANA, and then, later, confidently had LANe. Not worrying too much about ADo being US legislation, that gave me PeSToWATER for liquid gold.

Why not, I thought?!! Maybe there's a particular way of cooking in the Italian American community involving getting your pesto all watery before adding it to a dish.

So my nit here is with whoever decided to give Superboy a crush on someone called LANA when there's already someone called Lois Lane in your world. But maybe that was the point.

Nice, challenging, fresh Friday puzzle. Took me just about 2 minutes more than my average, but I appreciate stretching my brain to complete a puzzle with zero look-ups. The freshness of the clues and answers really gave my brain a good workout. Center of the grid — 35A and 35D — was the last to fall. 

Thanks for the workout.

Not more than half an hour before I ventured into this puzzle, in the course of burrowing down some Internet rabbit hole, did I happen to read the Wikipedia entry on former Rep Katie Porter. 
Why am I telling you this? It happens that she attended Grace Hopper College (formerly Calhoun College, after John C. Calhoun, an ardent defender of slavery) at Yale University. 
That rabbit hole paid off.

I did not care for the cluing in this one at all.  Combine that with what were for me quite a few obscure references (LANA, RAYE, GRACEHOPPER, a quote from Jane Eyre, HAW flakes?), and it made for a really unpleasant slog of a puzzle.  CANIS MAJOR, liquid gold, Caught Red-handed.  Ugh.  Does anyone look at PLAYMONEY and think to themselves, "this seems to be worth something?

53D is very poorly clued. An EON is a long period of time, while an ERA is a period of time marked by some person or event, like the often used “Obama era”. It doesn’t have to be long, as 8 years isn’t, just notable.

Quite delightful.
I needed a bit of thought for some synonyms, like BAIT, ENCRUST, LAND.
 A TEENY bit of the usual clues like ERA and ADA and I revealed and looked up GRACIE - interesting. 
Not too much film and pop culture, apart from HES, DRU and RAYE, which I didn't know, and one sports clue in LUIS.
Went straight to Wikipedia after this puzzle to learn more about GRACE HOPPER.  How could I NOT have known her story?
Thursday and Friday two beastly puzzles. Far in excess of my average solve times. Delighted to be sent down the Grace Hopper rabbit hole, what an extraordinary woman.

This is why I love a Friday puzzle.

Tough…until it’s not.
Sealed shut, until it busts open.
Slow…until it fills itself in, 
all chuffed and giddy-like.

And that having played hide-and-seek
and knowing OFF THE GRID,
“taught” me to look into
Grace Hopper!

Thank you Willa and Erik!

Happy Friday all!
Thank you, Willa and Erik. A great workout. 18A worth the price of admission.

Is it just me, or does everyone get nervous when they’re called to the boardroom to meet with the Hairdos?

(I hate tress codes. But I liked this puzzle.)

An enjoyable Friday. Typical tough workout, and had to look up a couple of things but just had a good time working things out from the crosses. And.. as a former mainframe programmer, GRACEHOPPER was an immediate gimme for me. 

Was quite surprised to see that FLYBALL, CANISMAJOR, CRIMEDRAMA and DONTYOUSEE were all debut answers. Seem like pretty familiar terms.  

And... interesting puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

About as clean and fun a construction as it gets.  Congrats to both creators.  

As pointed out by Yokohama Bill earlier. . .

TONI
INOT

. . . in the SE is pretty cool.  

Well done and thanks.

Got this yesterday from the care team at NYT.  Not totally satisfying but at least they see that there is a problem: 

Hi John,
 
The comment section may be showing fewer replies because only direct replies to the original comment are being displayed, while nested replies (replies to replies) might not be included in the initial view. This approach could be intended to streamline the viewing experience, reducing clutter in threads with many nested responses. However, I understand this makes the VAR function appear inconsistent, especially since it used to show after 3 replies, and now it’s not triggering reliably.
 
Your workaround of clicking the timestamp to display all replies, and the fact that emailed links show all replies, aligns with this explanation, the timestamp likely forces a full thread reload, including nested replies, while the email link bypasses the streamlined view. I’ve tested the thread you shared, and I can confirm the VAR button isn’t consistently appearing, which suggests a potential change in how we display replies.
 
I'll note this ticket as feedback for our team to review and consider as we continue to look for future improvements for our solvers, thank you.
What are the odds that GRACE HOPPER would have the same number of letters as Ada Lovelace?

P.S.

Pasta water may be liquid gold,
but USER BASE is people.

A delightfully al dente puzzle!
It took me a bit to realize that PASTA WATER was liquid gold. I had not heard of that, do not cook much, but wonder why starchy water would be deemed such? Anyway, this puzzle was done to perfection.

Now this...

 is a crossword puzzle!

The term “liquid gold” usually means clarified butter / ghee - I have never heard or seen it used to refer to pasta water. That doesn’t even make sense, as pasta water is by not gold by any stretch of the imagination!

Wow was that hard! 4 minutes over my average, but I felt the burn after crossing the finishing line and thought I'd worked for longer. [SEEKING COMMENT?] was *inspired*. I was sure "liquid gold" was butter or fat related, so that really caused me trouble. Had no idea about PEAR wood, making that a neat TIL. Didn't know the names LANA or LUIS, so felt like I took an L on those. Great job to the constructors on a challenging puzzle that hit a lot of gaps in my knowledge, but was still solvable thanks to quality construction.

DNF because refused to let go of crEW for 45 across. 

My bad!  


tc
After 4D and 17A clued as [Turf], I *so* wanted 34A, [Kick out], to be TURF. Maybe that only works in BrE, and only sortakinda.

Am I the only one who rolls their eyes when they see Erik's name? His clues are dense, he's far too proper noun heavy and the entire puzzle just smacks of his trying to be clever (emphasis on the TRYING). I can always manage to get through one of his puzzles...but I rarely have fun doing it.
Clever clues -- fun!  I liked seeing hoist, touts, and oust all grouped together.
Such a fun one today. Some dense cluing made clearer by the intersecting words, just as a crossword should be. Loved this much more than yesterday’s.

This, too, shall pasta.

(I spent way too much time trying to make "pot liquor" fit. Is that just a Southern thing?)

Good chewy puzzle, thanks, Willa and Erik.
I was really hoping that "Liquid gold" would turn out to be "Bacon grease".  Nothing against PASTA WATER, but gold?  Really???

the only liquid gold I know is the soup my meemaw makes

shoutout to eddie
Just once I'd like to see a Friday or Saturday without a bunch of obscure proper nouns

This was so much fun! Thank you to the constructors! My favorite clue/answer combo is 30D. Too cute! That, plus SEASHORE and PLAY MONEY are making me nostalgic for my childhood, which honestly doesn't happen all that often.

So, suddenly I have to Log In, meaning Go Look Up the last time I had this happen (and had to get a new password, which was in the last year or so, and of course I can't remember it without my LIST)....  which means I was already annoyed when I found that I finished with an error....  Good grief.
Oh well.  CLAY MONEY may become the Next Big Thing if the economy continues its downward-facing position....

I wanted IDA LOVELACE at 11D for the computer science pioneer.   And it  fit perfectly.

PASTA WATER is "liquid gold"?  How very disappointing.  
But
Congrats to Willa Angel Chen Miller and Erik the Agard.
"To find the bug, you must be the bug. Patience, young Grace Hopper."

So many things in today's puzzle to learn:
RAYE, EDM, DRU Hill, and, most importantly, GRACE HOPPER.

Hit my 365-day mark with this toughie. House guests a year ago compelled me to miss a day in my prior solving streak, but since then, no house guests, no missed puzzles.

Win-win! 

I guess.
Between yesterday and today, I think I'm losing my touch.

I would call myself a B minus solver, and I was able to finish this one in less than 30 minutes, no lookups.  It was satisfying to see that some regulars found it chewy … does that mean I’m now a B+ solver?  Proper nouns were easily figured out with the crosses.  Going to look up Grace Hopper!

I think there's an error between the Easy Mode Puzzle and the actual Friday puzzle in the lower right corner. 54 down Clue in easy mode is common meas. for baling soda ( TSP) and 56 across is  "-nosed kid"(SNOT)

I used Easy Mode and then transferred my answers to the actual puzzle and kept getting a "not quite right" message so I used Autocheck (didn't want to! lol)

Excellent puzle, especially READY OR NOT for [Seeking comment?].

I learned everything I know about The Little Mermaid from crossword puzzles, and I thought I learned one more thing today.  I first had Elsa at 31D because it seemed logical that she would say "no net ensnares me".

This one had me off balance the whole way through but I still managed to solve in a fairly brisk 15 minutes. 

Clever clueing!

Re: 22A
As  a kid learning to play baseball, I sorta had a general idea of how to play,  but had no glove. 
So when a hard hit ball came right at me, I caught it, but immediately dropped it out of my hot Red hand. 

Great puzzle!

Wow - what a Friday ! A ton of misdirection. Ada Lovelace instead of Grace Hopper ; Coax , lure - nope BAIT ; execs - nope - SUITS ; send - nope SHIP .. and I could go on ! This one took way more time than usual for me - but a great solve none the less. Ready or not - I finished .

Thaks Willa and Erik.


Finally, a crossword not hoisted by it's own petard.
ts pmo sybau fr ngl icl gurt

My first thought for 'liquid gold' was bacon fat. My mother saved it in a jar which was kept in the fridge and we used it for frying potatoes and the like, and my dad melted it and added it to waffle batter. Both were mighty tasty as a result, well, the cooked waffles of course! And hey, wasn't 'result' a yesterday's answer? I think it was! Anyway, perhaps using bacon fat for cooking is no longer to anyone's taste, but my parents' habits were shaped by the Depression and WW II era rationing, so yes, they followed the golden rule of those times, then and for the rest of their lives: 'Use it up, wear it out, make it do, or do without'. Now, pasta water? I love to cook and I've watched a lot of cooking shows, so I understand the use for it, but, I can't say I ever have. Have a good weekend everyone, and maybe make your mom some waffles, bacon fat or not.
V much a Friday puzzle! Probably shouldn’t have taken me as long as it did, but worth it. Was RED- a helpful clue or a misdirection? Both? ;) Glad to see a Jane EYRE quotation.

You know when it’s just not your day? I’ve spent the last 4 hours stuck in road works on a shopping trip that should have taken a leisurely 2 max. I finally make it home and put my feet up to do the crossword. Naturally I find it fiendishly difficult because my brain has turned to mush.
I congratulate myself on getting Ada Lovelace. It isn’t her. Half of the phrases I’ve never come across, so crawl through all the permutations at a snails pace, recreating this morning’s fiasco. The only gimme is the divine Miss EYRE. Yay, my BA Lit has its uses, even if it’s eternally the Brontë sisters. I move 300 miles away from the outskirts of their village and still they haunt me through the squares of the crossword.

I then write my comment, which mysteriously deletes itself before I can submit. So this is attempt #2. 

I’m off to recoup my zen with the Alpacas. Toodles.
Harder than it should have been. Still, with Deb’s help was able to get a better hold. Ending up being a very nice puzzle - just not in my wheel house. Thanks!
I came here to say that this was a perfect puzzle, and only then did I realize Erik Agard had a hand in it!  He’s the best. 😊
Just plain wonderful.
I learned today that “ITSALLGOOD” has exactly the same number of letters as “INEEDARIDE”. 👍

I thought Liquid Gold was what my mom used on the kitchen
cabinets.

Avoid spoilers, plz, till "view all replies".

Yesterday's Strands posts got buried in the thousand comments.

Strands #432
“Outsiders”
🔵🔵🟡🔵
🔵🔵🔵
Some people are just crabby.

And on another note: did 42A trigger memories of the delicious dialog between McCrea and Coburn in "The More the Merrier" (1943) for anyone else? 

    Joe Carter: What do you do?
    Benjamin Dingle: I'm a well-to-do, retired millionaire. How about you?
    Joe Carter: Same.

[Meaning, not "That's my opinion, too," but "Sure, whatever ridiculous thing you say"; here loaded with irony.]

Just see it!

How many times have I had to remind Mr. Beth not to pour out the $&#@* PASTA WATER? It's not PLAY MONEY we're dealing with here!

This puzzle seemed very straightforward to me with less Wordplay than I've seen in many Fridays. Hopefully folks who hated yesterday's trickiness will be soothed by this one.

Despite several answers I didn't know (CANIS MAJOR, GRACE HOPPER, LUIS Robert Jr) all came together through crosses and logic. Didn't know 39D, but how many 4-letter Spanish words for numbers are there? Tres didn't work, so changed it to SEIS. 46D was first Lois, then LANEe, and finally LANA.
Very much enjoyed being in the know on haw flakes. So obscure! Blast from my past used to buy these rolls for a dime at the corner Asian market in my neighbors in SF.

Not sure if anyone else noticed, but DC from Weston had an interesting post yesterday about the new pope, the Augustinians, and Villanova University. It seems to be gone. Off topic, controversial, not sure why that happened. Any ideas?

What a great workout! I took a shot on OFFTHEGRID, ONEANDDONE and READYORNOT and was thrilled when they all worked out. I was not so lucky with endusers before USERBASE, but TOFU sorted that out. I had tEAk before PEAR and had to fix that area to get the gold. 

ATALLHOURS was refreshing!  It made up for the PST, DST… crosswordese that I don’t typically love lol.
Perfect Friday puzzle for me, not too easy and not too tough

This one started out slowly for me due to some faulty assumptions - today I learned ADA LOVELACE and GRACE HOPPER have the same number of letters, as do CRIME DRAMA and PROCEDURAL - but once I caught on the sailing was pretty smooth. Thanks for the fun!

So, so, so many wrong guesses led me astray.

But good puzzles are like that.

My first time through the puzzle on the across clues yielded nada 👎. Kept at it and with some of the down clues OFFTHEGRID opened things up. Fun solve not too easy and definitely gave my brain a workout. Especially liked 57A and always save some just in case 😃🍝. 43A had me for a few minutes - haven’t heard that term since my grandma 🤷‍♀️and she’s been gone for 18 yrs. Bravo 👏 on a fun Friday!
48A You’ll still hear a lot around Liverpool.

Mini Crossword for Fri, 5/9/2025, clue about cartoon bear. Not a cartoon. Fictional bear, seen in illustrations or, yes, cartoon version from the illustrations. My point is that I had the answer, but questioned it being correct, because the wording implies the source, not cartoons. Yogi and BooBoo are cartoon bears.

Finished this in half the time it took me to finish yesterday's!

Kudos to the constructor for CANISMAJOR, among others.

What fun!
Loved this puzzle, but I hesitated with NOT being used twice.  I thought there was some kind of rule about that.

Very well made puzzle. Lots of interesting entries and few clunkers (like ITOO and INOT, which were made more interesting by being symmetrically paired).

As seems to be the case when a puzzle has many long phrases, I found this one rather easy. Filled in OFFTHEGRID and ONEANDDONE immediately, and several others came quite quickly. Not a fast solver, but this one was done in less than 25 minutes. Didn't know RAYE, but did know the adjacent BEALE, which helped near the center of the grid.

Still trying to comprehend how CANISMAJOR is "downward-facing", but maybe I'll rely on the comments for that.

A tricky Thursday and a tough themeless on Friday!  I can’t wait for Saturday. 

And don't throw the past away
You might need it some rainy day
Dreams can come true again
When everything old is new again.
With Lewis not around today to point this out, please note that at 54A and 56A we have a palindromic pair, with TONI directly above INOT.

Deb once gave a piece of advice along the lines of: relax, your brain knows this. To one who is circling 70, and who cared for a mom with dementia, memory is a fragile, fickle-fingered thing. While i can, i wait for these figures to walk back to me and often they still come.

Haw flakes. Toni Morrison. Free trade. James Baldwin. 

Boss, i'm ok.
Thought "liquid gold" was CHICKENFAT for the longest time. PASTAWATER is not nearly as exquisite, imo. Crunchy and fun puzzle today!
In my (admittedly limited) world, holding a thumb up might indicate agreement or “I’m OK.”  Holding a thumb out, on the other hand, or the same hand for that matter, might get the desired result.
Frisky Friday...loved it! thanks Angel and Erik!

Sigh. I have become an old person who does not readily know phrases like ONEANDDONE.

Oh well I knew PLAYMONEY.

Thank you Will and Eric

ps. Ida Lovelace fit as well... but was wrong.

Longtime comments lurker, first time poster 39A cluing immediately recalled the Vine that lives forever rent free in my mind: https://youtube.com/shorts/BgeWu2XGjvE?si=z_UZe_ogks9K3jrR https://time.com/3508424/michelle-obama-turnip-for-what-vine/
See, "liquid gold" to me is "chicken fat" which is incredibly useful when rendered out and is also the proper color!

I liked today’s puzzle. And yesterday’s puzzle… though I assume we were divided on that. I’ve not checked out the comments but anytime a puzzle goes off grid, there’ll be pushback! I’m catching up after giving up phone games/socials for Lent. It’s nice to be back. 

Do many people use xwstats website? Just curious who contributes to the median data.

I'm intrigued that so many people here went for the very English Ada, Countess of Lovelace, rather than the truly fabulous and home-grown American GRACE HOPPER.

Seems like she should be more famous in her own country. I had no idea she had a college named after her (I do believe there's a *ship* named after her), but when I saw "pioneer in computer science" and "Yale", I had Hopper's name in there straight away.

Another tough one for me today but I got 'er done! Huzzah! 

The vast majority of my puzzles are unaided these days but when Friday and Saturday seem to be properly more difficult, it gets dicey for me. I did not think I was going to be able to finish it a few times but I am trying to build my confidence, so I just kept at it... putting answers in, taking answers out, occasionally being able to put them back in, and voila!  I did it in (definitely slower than average but) a reasonable for me time. Most importantly, I really enjoyed it! 

After the first full round, all I had that could remain was EYRE, TONI, and ITOO. I guess that might be somewhat telling of my wheelhouse. Har! 

Anyhow, very enjoyable with a SLEW of fun clues and great misdirects! 

If I had to pick a favorite entry, it would probably be READYORNOT. 

As for PASTAWATER, ITOO have never heard it called that but am a huge believer in its benefits. I will start calling it liquid gold effective immediately! Sometimes my husband cooks the pasta, though I always make the sauces, so it'll be fun to remind him to save the liquid gold! Much more fun than "Don't forget to scoop out some water before you drain it..." Borrrrring!
This was perfect for a Friday! The right combo of challenge + solvability.
When hitchhiking, the thumb is not ‘up’. It points in the direction you want to go. It would appear that those responsible for this clue, have not hitchhiked.

Don't you see?

I don't practice any of the OCCULT arts such as Tarot or Cartomancy.  

But...it's hard to ignore the two SUITS in Friday's puzzle.
HEARTs & SPADEs.  
A 6 of Hearts and a 6 of SPADEs.
If you google the Tarot and Cartomancy significance of these two cards you will be surprised.

Even more surprising was Thursday's puzzle which contained
the 9 of SPADEs.
I'll leave you to discover this on your own.

Wishing pleasant memories, new and old, to everyone on Mother's Day.

I try not to complain about these puzzles because they are games and not worth getting upset about.

But, in case the editors read these comments at all to understand the cruciverbalist vibe, may I say that I, like some others, have noted that the crosswords have gotten easier. I prefer them when they are more challenging. Yesterday’s hit a sweet spot that I have been missing. Today’s was fun, but, can we have some a bit more challenging please?
Can someone please explain what a "counterpart" is to the constructors of the mini crossword? They use it incorrectly constantly. Drives me nuts.

I see that some thought this one was easy. I enjoyed the solve, but certainly didn’t feel it was too easy, and I needed some of Deb’s Tricky Clues. My last spot to fill was the SW corner. For a long time I had the DR of DRU, and S__ITS at 44D. Hadn’t heard of DRU Hill, but really should have seen SUITS much earlier. 🤦🏼‍♀️🤦🏼‍♀️. Oh well, it was a challenging puzzle for me, but an enjoyable one. Thanks Willa and Erik, and Deb too. 
I’ve been reading a wonderful novel lately, “The Magician” by Colm Toiban, about the life and work of Thomas Mann. I had read some of Mann’s novels, but didn’t really know much about his life, and his years spent in the U.S. during WWII. I recommend it if you’re looking for an absorbing read.

This was an odd one for me. I flew through most of it only to get utterly stumped in the southwest. If not for that, I would’ve heard the happy music in half the time as I did yesterday. As is, I was only a few minutes faster. It’s almost certainly on me rather than the puzzle, but that’s my least favorite sort of solve. Maybe i just couldn’t recover from LANA instead of Lois and PASTAWATER instead of bacon fat, which didn’t fit in any way other than obviously being liquid gold. 

Speaking of Mr. Caprera puzzle, though—more like that, please. Reasonably difficult throughout but with a clever butt joke to really ratchet things up. Fun fun fun.

GRACEHOPPER was a gimme. I heard her speak at BYU in about 1970 when I was an undergrad in Computer Science. She told us some day we would all have our own computer on our desks! And they would be connected!! This was the heydey of IBM and Univac mainframes. We couldn't imagine such a thing. And here's info about a lecture she did in 1982 about cyber security. She was alway a woman way ahead of her time. We can now watch Grace Hopper’s famed 1982 lecture on YouTube The lecture featured Hopper discussing future challenges of protecting information. Read in Ars Technica: https://apple.news/AYx1QGHDNS2eOPamTOtipJg

Took me almost an hour but did with no help so not easy but more so than yesterday, for me. I got tripped up on the middle right side. Just finally dawned on me. Help from crosses. Thank you, Willa and Erik! I think that’s what Fridays or Saturdays are like when the going is good.

For years, puzzles after Wednesdays were frequently beyond me, but I’ve been getting better! For several weeks now, I’ve been doing Friday on “easy mode” first, to try and build my crossword vocabulary. Today I noticed a discrepancy—the first letter of 56A is different in the two versions of the puzzle! 

Has this ever happened before?? Was it an error, or just another way to make “easy mode” more accessible?
instead of "pastawater," I was stuck on "chickenfat," my personal liquid gold

A stunning Friday! Solved it with a friend immediately after finishing up yesterday's (I'm glad to be among the seemingly few that enjoyed the outside-the-box theme- it was my birthday puzzle!)

We definitely worked our brains with two back-to-back tricky puzzles but I was delighted by how lively and clean the fill in this one was. My favorite entries were OFFTHEGRID, READYORNOT, PLAYMONEY, and BITTERSWEET. So impressed with how jam-packed it is with fun entries tho; a feat of crossword construction. So much fun all around!!!! Thank you Willa and Erik!

@W johnson people often use crackers when they have baked brie.  It's soft and gooey, and you spread it on a cracker, maybe with a little pepper jelly or fig jam.  My wife loves it.

@W johnson My daughter who lives in France laughed at us when we were visiting, looking for crackers to consume with our cheese. It is VERY HARD to find crackers in France! Fortunately a baguette serves the purpose even better (alas, it is very difficult to find a good baguette in the US!)

@W johnson definitely different cultural and culinary norms. In the US, crackers are a common vehicle for just about any kind of cheese. So much so that “cheese and crackers” is a common phrase. Probably most people in the US would think it odd to consume a hunk of cheese just by itself (unless it’s a cheese curd). Personally, I prefer my Brie on a thin slice of baguette, but a cracker will do in a pinch. I don’t doubt that there are many French culinary practices that other cultures would find degoutant. 😉

Personally, I thought the Red-handed clue was excellent, but you do have to know of the existence of the Cincinnati Reds to appreciate it, and more generally know a little about baseball. 

READY OR NOT was also very clever IMO, but absolutely requires a cultural background that many outside the US likely wouldn’t have.

You save it for sauces heating on the stovetop, to keep them from drying out when the pasta is added;  eg, when making linguine and clams, shrimp fra diavolo.  Adds a little richness.

@Christine Whittington 

Radar technicians were using the term before she did, though. Not to downplay her contribution to computer science, of course. She may have been aware of the term, and finding a literal 'bug' in a system may have just amused her.

Bug as an engineering problem predates radar. Edison used the term in his personal notes and correspondence to mean a difficult problem that needed solving or an engineering defect that needed fixing. He even joked about the term being related to insects, writing in an 1878 letter: "You were partly correct, I did find a 'bug' in my apparatus, but it was not in the telephone proper. It was of the genus 'callbellum.' The insect appears to find conditions for its existence in all call apparatus of Telephones." https://www.howtogeek.com/726020/what-is-a-computer-bug-and-where-did-the-term-come-from/

Peabody,

In one of those neat coincidences, just a couple days ago I was watching a video about the construction of hurdy-gurdies, and was struck by their use of pear wood. I was surprised that pear trees got large enough for some of the lumber they were cutting.

@Peabody
Same here. My guitar is made of Koa, Spruce and Ebony. Wasn't aware of Pear wood, either.

@Peabody
I thought those woodwinds were made of ebony, but it turns out that pearwood is highly resistant to moisture (saliva) and is dyed black to look like ebony. My Les Paul is mahogany with a maple top, and it's pretty heavy, but that tight-grained wood is great for sustain.

@Tim L.L. are the initials for many Superman characters who, for the most part, have tended to be his adversaries, love interests, or relatives. https://superman.fandom.com/wiki/LL It's been a running gag almost as long as Superman's been around, and no one really knows why. There's tons of L.L. characters in the older comics. Even Superman has commented on how weird of a coincidence it is. One rumor is that Shuster's first girlfriend had those initials, but it's never been confirmed.
@Francine Thanks, good to know!!!

@Tim
LANA Lang before Lois Lane, and also Lori Lemaris, a mermaid in human disguise whom young Clark meets at college. And Lara is Kal-El's mother's name. As Francine points out, it's a running gag.

Thank you for sharing that.  I went the same route as @Tim, with Lois, then LANe, and finally LANA.  Had no idea LL was a "thing" as I haven't really followed DC Comics as much as Marvel.

@The X-Phile
I looked up the HAW flakes which are from the Chinese or Asian hawthorn tree, not the European one. Several different hawthorns grow in the USA. 
There is a lot of mythology around hawthorn trees, they can live for up to 400 years.
In Scotland they are known as the May tree, giving rise to the saying that you shouldn't leave off warm clothes until the may tree is in flower:
"N'er cast a clout till may be oot."

Oikofuge,

I suspect it has something to do with the fact that "grace" and "hopper" have never been related clues and answers in The Times Crossword (GRACEHOPPER is a debut) ... but a significant number of the 258 ADA in the "Modern Era" have been clued to "Lovelace."

@Oikofuge

A and D are common letters, and ADA is short. That makes for a useful fill word. Ada is along for the ride.

@Oikofuge
I first thought of Ada Lovelace, as well. I changed it when the crosses didn't fit. But they have the same number of letters. Coincidence?  I think not...

I thought of Lady Lovelace, too, but couldn't think why a Yale college would be named after her---maybe a failure of imagination on my part. 
Rear-Admiral Hopper seemed by far the better bet, based on an assessment of real-world probabilities rather than crosswordese, so in she went.

@Oikofuge, I had Lovelace first, but as soon as I realized my error, I knew who it was. Grace Murray Hopper spoke at my brother's college graduation in 1985, at The College of William & Mary. I thoroughly enjoyed her address.

@Oikofuge
Even the US Department of Defense, when commissioning the development of a new programming language with certain features meant to make its systems more robust, chose to name it after Lord Byron’s daughter, rather than Ms. Hopper.

@Nick

The DoD has a programming language called Ada; the US Navy has a supercomputer called Grace.
@Bob of Newton I never knew this and I'm sure I'm never going to forget it now lol.  It'll live in the space of random facts my brain keeps :) Thank you!

@Bob of Newton

That's interesting.
In my part of the world, a hitchhiker faces the oncoming traffic, roadside arm extended, the thumb very definitely displayed pointing upwards and maybe very slightly backwards.
On quiet roads, we sometimes walk down the side of the road, and half turn with arm extended in the above fashion (thumb perhaps now tilted slightly forward), when we hear oncoming traffic.
The object of the exercise is to make sure the thumb is prominently visible to motorists---the direction of travel is indicated by the side of the road chosen, and by the traffic you signal to.

I've never hitched with my thumb pointing other than almost entirely vertically, and I don't recall seeing anyone else doing that.
Maybe there are different hitchhiking dialects in the US/UK, like the difference between ASL and BSL?

@Oikofuge

That was my experience in the seventies.

In any of the above cases, 
the thumb is "up" as in fully extended, 
while the other four fingers remain clenched.
